values:
probably because of hourly comics and because I am trying to get work done.

In any case, sometimes websites recommend things to me like books or music.  This is usually at least one suggestion that makes me wonder think that either this technology is not so far along, advertising is evil, or I have really really terrible taste.
o, i have an idea.  new new year's resolution.  post in this at least once a year.  lul.

This makes me happy, but kind of not.

I may not have told many people. But I took sabbatical from LJ during the summer. I didn't read others, (mostly), and I didn't make any posts except a couple privates. I did this partially because I am writing an exchange journal with my partner emily, and partly because I get fed up with LJ. c'est la vie.

i've just moved into a new apartment in northampton. it is beautiful - large, good view, lush douglas fir floors, nice kitchen (dishwasher + disposal) and a new roomate that I am already friends with. I have never lived with a friend before (in all of my 4 previous apartments) and already I like it. It is a little incestuous, but of the culturally accepted sort.

i stole a book from the canton public library. wait, actually i took it and eventually paid the fine for a lost book. i may have done this intentionally. it may be out of print, i'm not sure. mind breaths by allen ginsburg. it is probably my favorite work of poetry. i loaned it to a friend. we actually traded (she gave me howl and other works). i never got it back. this was some 7 years ago perhaps. now, i live with her, and she has it!

MANIFESTO
Let me say beginning I don't believe in Soul
The heart, famous heart's a bag of shit I wrote 25 years ago
O my immortal soul! youthful poet Shelley cried
O my immortal Ego -- little knowing
he didn't believe in God. Neither do I.
Nor all science reason reality and good moral Will --
collections of empty atoms as Kerouac Buddha scribed

Neither does great love immortal defy pain nightmare Death
    Torture Saigon Police Underground Press Pravda Bill of Rights--
And while we're at it, let's denounce Democracy, Fascism,
    Communism and heroes.
Art's not empty if it show's its own emptiness
Poetry useful leaves its own skeleton hanging in the air
like Buddha, Shakespeare & Rimbaud.
Serious, dispense with law except Cause & Effect, even the
    latter has exceptions
No cause & effect is not foolproof.
There is Awareness -- which confounds the Soul, Heart, God,
    Science Love Government and Cause & Effects' Night-
    mare.

18 Jan 1974 1 am
Find your own pose!

i'm home from scotland (and the rest of that island), unfortunately. not that there isn't any good to being home. plenty of friends, too many really. sunshine, amherst, familiarity, yoga, drucqs in people. speaking of these last two. on yoga. i decided to do bikram yoga for awhile to get in shape sort of before i went back to doing kung fu. there's a sweet intro deal at bikram yoga amherst, which is actually in sunderland. the first day of my intro i noticed a strong scent of fresh linens. pleasant, thought i, innocently, before my mind wandered down the path to more empirical thoughts. smell of fresh linen always reminds me of cunt. in a good way of course. something about fresh clean pussy and fresh clean underwear? or all laundry. so there's a lot of clean laundry at yoga i think, after all, this smell is intense. second day of yoga, after witnessing a close up view of the late middle aged woman in front of me's crotch in her bikini shorts then noticing the smell again. well, i put one and one together and realized that there's a good chance what i was smelling wasn't clean laundry, considering everyone in the room is dripping sweat like a condenser. my voyeurism reached a new level. i followed the mechanical animal into another room to watch him kiss an angel. shoot some blow. not v. disturbing really. warnings about blood because of built of scar tissue and dull needles. barely saw the lighter and the spoon. water mixed with powder, etc. yawn. seeing emily was great. scotland was so-so. when i describe it people i feel like i'm not living up to their expectations. no wild stories. the beautiful scenery is dull in haze, stone, bare mountains, and sheep. the culture is where our own derives from largely. hanging out with em was great though. we didn't get v. stressed with each other. there was one time in glasgow that we got upset over reading a map, but it lasted all of five minutes and we were both in terrible moods for other reasons too. sorry about that day em. there really were a few bumps on our traveling around, mostly sicknesses of varied sorts. we were v. lucky to have free accommodations except for two nights during The Haggis Tour of the Isle of Skye and the Highlands. We stayed in a B&B for those nights, and it was really nice. Cute bed, our own bathroom to shower together in, breakfast to order in the morning. mmm. my friend of a friend andy was extremely hospitable to let us stay in his bed for 4 nights and then hook us up with a friend in glasgow who even had a spare bedroom. what luck! i felt really connected to emily. especially as the trip drew to a close, the sense of urgency to feel each other's presence was overwhelming and i can't say i'm glad to have left. all in all it was really cool to go to other counties(did i mention england and wales and driving on the left?) than my own and to share it with someone i love. i have so much to do now that i'm back. study for gre's, research grad schools, and figure out what i'm doing after august. if i'm getting a new job or not. i don't want to make less money, but i also want to be doing something where i'm getting positive professional experience. here's a quaint pic from Dundee More, and more later.

I would "love" to hear some thoughts on these



"Most people who fall in love have masturbated for a considerable time, and are accustomed to quick, reflex satisfaction whenever they want it."

"We do not fall in love until we suspect we are ready to leave our parents, and unless we are capable of making a new, dependent attachment."

"In the ideal progression, if marriage results, any threat to the union will deepend it....seperation aniety....apartness....difficulties with children will only create a firmer bonding."

"Perhaps the greatest intimacy of an ideal marriage is to turn to sex in death and loss and grief.  To go to a funeral is to have sex afterward, if you can."

going on to say

"Sex in marriage is the darkest and the best, a celebration of life's most capricious glory and its most permanent sorrow, when one faces seperation from existence itself.

one of those days i did actually take a nap. it was awesome.  i missed the dreary evening, hung out for a couple hours with carly and jesse and fel and d and michelle.  

everybody who's anybody.

i think this line is somewhat interesting.  or maybe i'm just a culture whore.

i'm supposed to spend the week in bed.  i wrote that in my paper journal last night.  i'm supposed to come home from whatever it is that i'm doing and go to bed.  its 12:30... i was ^in^ bed for about two hours.  but i didn't try to sleep or anything.  this is mostly an attempt on my part to ACTUALLY SLEEP, despite being desperately hateful and afraid of most types of sleep.  and i don't mean afraid of the boogeyman.  i mean afraid that when i go to sleep i die, that the more i sleep the less i like myself, or am myself.  it doesn't count if i go to sleep naturally.

but on the flip side...

maybe if i go to bed when i get home from (insert scheduled activity here) i could wake up and enjoy the wee hours (12-5) which is my favorite time of day.  at least to be alone.

























and my other reason for updating?  I'M GOING TO SCOTLAND IN A WEEK!! HOLY MEAT ON A SHISHKABOBBITT!!!

okay, so...  i apparently miscalculated...  the not so suicide note below has nothing to do with me except that i put it on my journal, as a link, to postsecret.

sometimes i'm driving and i see one of those jesus fish with the little cross for an eye and i get an overwhelming urget to just lay on my horn.  it's like, yeah i'm honking at you, you fucking bible banger, i don't care.  get your non-secular laws and culture out of my fucking life.  but then i'm like, oh they're probably just trying to be nice.  lataz.

melissa

"i need to be useful"
adina

"yeah...yeah...yeah..."
Fel (taken out of context for writer's reasons)

ffffffffffuuuuucccckkkkk.
has anyone travelled to germany or the czech republic?  i don't have health insurance and it says i need it to go to those countries, where i am supposed to go in a little bit.  does anyone know about travellers insurance?
ahhhhhh (see below for more).

cutting callouses with so much mental scissors.
lets see what's underneath.
dressed up to go to the supermarket.  too accepted in my own head.

emily leaves for scotland on sunday : (.  i miss her so much already.  it really is a sort of low deep hum of a feeling, intense, but in a low hum sort of way...

no hugs for awhile.  or asljfht.   



i think that this state of having a girlfriend - that isn't around - feels like a return to innocence in a way.  the impossibility of sex, of physical intimacy and love, and the feeling of life's stagnancy wrapping around oneself without others persistent image distracting...

hmmm

emily left today
i've been feeling gray
nay lay fay may pay ray

i pulled a muscle in the weirdest place today (as in not that i was crawling under a porch building a soffet and turning my hands black).  i guess its sort of my hip.  right below the top of it.  on the surface, not deep at all.  it's really annoying, because it's like a soft dull pain everytime i move.

borrowed from  <lj user="xenophobe">

1. What did you do in 2005 that you'd never done before?
work full time for more than 3 months straight

2. Did you keep your new years' resolutions, and will you make more for next year?
umm, i don't remember what resolutions i made, so probably not.  and maybe i will, but more like i will make plans.

3. Did anyone close to you give birth?
unfortunately not

4. Did anyone close to you die?
nooo

5. What countries did you visit?
some. the u.s., oh and i read a book that took place in czechoslovakia

6. What would you like to have in 2006 that you lacked in 2005?
a better identity.

7. What date from 2005 will remain etched upon your memory, and why?
...

8. What was your biggest achievement of the year?
getting my job

9. What was your biggest failure?
not helping emily enough

10. Did you suffer illness or injury?
i fucked my shoulder up.  i missed work and could barely drive.  

11. What was the best thing you bought?
a hat and sweater from H&M

12. Whose behaviour merited celebration?
fel, he's really kicking this whole art major animation concentration thing

13. Whose behaviour made you appalled and depressed?
people who haze people make me appalled.  my own behaviour may have made me depressed.

14. Where did most of your money go?
eating out.

15. What did you get really, really, really excited about?
going to europe this coming spring

16. What song will always remind you of 2005?
songs don't remind me of years

17. Compared to this time last year, are you:


i. Happier or sadder?
sadder probably.  i don't like not being a full time student anymore, its more tedious.

ii. Thinner or fatter?
sort of thinner i think.

iii. richer or poorer?
well, more income, more debt

18. What do you wish you'd done more of?
reading.

19. What do you wish you'd done less of?
watching tv

20. How will you be spending Christmas?
being sad about not having christmas morning anymore. but i'll be happy in the afternoon and evening.

23. How many one-night stands?
nope.

24. What was your favourite TV program?
i rented a lot of six feet under.  

25. Do you hate anyone now that you didn't hate this time last year?
no one ever does anything bad to me. i appear to be lucky like that.

26. What was the best book you read?
i don't think any stand out.

27. What was your greatest musical discovery?
Eels.

28. What did you want and get?
i think i wanted more space from emily and to live in amherst.  which i wanted, and now i have mixed feelings.

29. What was your favourite film of this year?
buffalo 66 was pretty great.

31. What did you do on your birthday, and how old were you?
awe jeez, mines in january...  i think my friends rocked a get together, i think my family rocked a cake and presents thing, and i think my gf took me out and some other stuff.  23.

33. How would you describe your personal fashion concept in 2005?
well, i've tried to push towards tighter pants and stripier things.  also, the carpentry thing has made my carhartts and long johns collection expand a little too much...

34. What kept you sane?
the feeling that people still think i'm weird.

35. Which celebrity/public figure did you fancy the most?
i don't know, but it was probably a boy.

36. What political issue stirred you the most?
the realization that politically charged times destroys my sense of individualism and any chance at happiness.  i am now officially trying not to think about it.

37. Who did you miss?
joe adina and rebecca.  a lot.

38. Who was the best new person you met?
adam.

39. Tell us a valuable life lesson you learned in 2005:
shut up and think.

40. Quote a song lyric that sums up your year:
"as if" that could work.  but ummm,  "I don't really see, how things will improve, if all you want is to stay loose" - B&S

the myth:
8 (or so) things to do after work today

the reality:
dinner, followed by irrating to meanable stomach ache.

what i've eaten in the last 24 hours(or so) (and why they might be hurting my stomach):

reese's peanut butter cups - 4 last night (not likely a source of any long term illness, could contribute to indigestion)

sushi - dynamite roll (coincidental name...), half salmon roll, half yellow tail roll (food poisoning, harmful to lethal bacteria, tapeworm, and all that soy sauce and wasabi certainly help the case for indegestion)

ice cream - large,half cookie dough/peanut butter swirl and half cake batter fudge swirl (food poisoning and bacteria if gone bad,or if bad ingredients used in making, again indigestion makes a case here)

half a bagel - lots of butter (probably safe, but i've eaten like half a stick of butter on bagels this week)

that was all last night
today i had

breakfast - a bagel and an apple  (not too much to worry about here, same with the butter)

lunch - my homemade soup (very suspect, tons of butter, also chicken which was once frozen and curry)
        coffee/chai combo (really strong case for indigestion, but ulcers come to mind as well)
        orange (acid?)
        turkey cookie (actually called clamshell cookie.  shellfish poisoning?jk, no fish involved. just frosting.)

        another four reese's cups before dinner

dinner - heres the kicker.  onions, oil, hot sauce, barbecue sauce old brocolli (we're talkin limp) and chicken that was frozen for a month, and then in the fridge for 5 days, then cooked (indigestion, salmonella, other bacteria, whatever you can get from bad veggies)

and technically, 3 doses of the pink stuff.  and the other half of that bagel, but all after i started being sick.

oh, and stress?  i don't know if i have stress.  what does it feel like?  is it sort of like your wanting to bash your head against your desk, or is it more of a geyser building in your gut and creaking out through your eyes?

so.  i doubt the ice cream or sushi did it.  unless emily feels sick.  i hope it wasn't the chicken cause then i might be in deep shit with chicken bacteria.  i hope its not an ulcer (because sometimes my stomach feels...weird) and i hope it's not indigestion cause i hate the idea of not having a stomach of steel.  actually, i hope i have the stomach flue and have to stay in the bathroom for the next week, cause at least then i'll get some reading done.

firstly, what does ----------------

leather elbows 
on a tweed coat
oh -
is that the best you can do?

yes, i am blind.

------------
add up to?
hmm... 
i'll be glad to take a stab at it, but it might save trouble if you can tell me.  sorry if i sound tense, see below.


second (segundo) - has anyone been watching the new boondocks show?  i think its pretty good, probably better than the strip, and probably won't last because it looks like its trying to be funny, but it isn't.

third - people and me and their compaints about me and my understanding of said compaints about me.
so i argue with everything everyone says.  is it really my fault that some people can't understand that i don't take things seriously enough to argue with them out of spite or malice?  if i question something you say, don't assume its a personal attack.  i don't need a reason to question, its my natural state.  so sue me (at least for using this cliche line).  also connected to the constant inflammation of egos around me (due to their owners being defensive in the face of my well intentioned prodding) is something of people never getting when i'm being sarcastic.  at least lately they don't get it.  can't you understand that i probably didn't mean it if i say something that sounds nasty? no? well okay, then that's probably my fault.  i've hated on peeps before for having faulty communication of their sarcasm.  it sucks, i shouldn't let it happen.  

fourth - expect something special from this journal soon.  excerpts from a found journal.  booyah.

can someone please tell me how to have a little more self control.  i'm having a bad streak.  i have a ton of work to do for tuesdays spanish class and i've done less than a third of it.  all of it should have been done way in advance so i would learn it and remember it (i have a solo class presentation to give).  

and if you think that i'll probably pull it all together somehow, you're wrong.  i suck at this.



well, in reality i could be decent.  but it would require a bunch of focus and determination to catch up that, frankly, i just don't seem to have right now. go fig.

seeking solutions to the

there's an interesting thought that has entered my mind recently.  it came as a result of a conversation i was having about being a whole person.  i was just trying to make a point and i said that we might have all these 'strings' attached to us that are supposed to be attached to certain things.  and it stands to reason that since we can't even see these 'strings', then maybe there are ones that go to things that we have no idea about.  and maybe we have loose 'strings' - ones that are supposed to go somewhere, but don't.  the places that they are supposed to go could be completely and totally foreign, unimaginable, and incomprehensible to us.  another friend was trying to point out something about balance and he ended up giving me a really good example of how this could be.  he said that you can't see dark if you don't have light - you wouldn't recognize it for dark without something to compare it too.   one sort of these strings could be to things that we don't understand because there is no opposite, nothing else that relates to them.    i can't give too definitive an example of what i mean, because it seems that there should be unknowable things that exist.

with all the natural disasters (tsunami, hurricane/flooding, and earthquake in pakistan with up to 20,000 dead) and wars (iraw, sudan, some more i didn't hear about) i'm suprised i haven't heard any touting about the end of the world.

i think that bill murray's face in the last scene of broken flowers was one of the most empathetic moments i've shared with a character, despite not being a don juan or likely ever having an unknown child.

I think they went kite flying this morning.  I hope it works out.  She said they made an awkward pair.  He seems optimistic.
Broken Flowers was....interesting.  Mostly I didn't get what made him a Don Juan, except that he went through a year period in which he did it with 5 girls.  I can't decide what the title means.  Obviously this Don wants a little more out of life, so maybe he's broken.  The fact that the flowers work make them broken (not that they work that much).  at the end of the movie he's standing there (no flowers to be seen) and he's just made a fool of himself, and is going through all these thoughts about who his son is, who he would be.  That sort of moment is like practically a cliche of my life.  All bound up.
